metadata.title: Multiple known and a novel parvovirus associated with an outbreak of feline diarrhea and vomiting

abstract.text: An unexplained outbreak of feline diarrhea and vomiting, negative for common 25 enteric viral and bacterial pathogens, was subjected to viral metagenomics and PCR. We 26 characterized from fecal samples the genome of a novel chapparvovirus we named fechavirus 27 that was shed by 8/17 affected cats and different feline bocaviruses shed by 9/17 cats. Also 28 detected were nucleic acids from attenuated vaccine viruses, members of the normal feline 29 virome, viruses found in only one or two cases, and viruses likely derived from ingested food 30 products. Epidemiological investigation of disease signs, time of onset, and transfers of affected 31 cats between three facilities support a possible role for this new chapparvovirus in a highly 32 contagious feline diarrhea and vomiting disease. 33 34 35

body_text.text: Cats have an estimated world-wide population of over half a billion. Members Shelter 3 became involved in the outbreak when a cat (#160) transferred from Shelter 2 became 148 sick, several days after arrival and before the outbreak had been identified. Ultimately, a total 13 149 cats were affected in Shelter 1 in November, 17 cats were affected in Shelter 2 (November -150 January), and 13 cats were affected in Shelter 3 (November-January) (Figure 1 and 151 Supplementary Table 1 ). Nearly all transmission was indirect ( Figure 2) ; because of this, it was 152 not possible to definitively determine which animals had been exposed, except in specific rooms 153 where housing was communal or exposure was known to be widespread prior to introduction of 154 control measures. Attack rates for these rooms were 66.7% (Shelter 2) and 83.3% (Shelter 3) 155 (Table 1) . 156

Overall, diarrhea and vomiting were observed in 81.4% and 67.4% of the 43 cases. There 157 were likely more cats vomiting because vomitus that could not be attributed to a particular cat 158 was found multiple times in the final wave of illness. 25.6% and 11.6% of the affected cats also 159 showed inappetence and lethargy, and 67.4% required veterinary care ( Table 2 ). The minimum 160 incubation period was 24 hours, and the maximum was estimated at 5-7 days based on estimated 161 exposure dates. Vomiting tended to start 1-2 days before diarrhea, and last only a couple of days, 162 but in some animals the diarrhea lasted up to a week (longer in a few animals). The mean 163 duration of illness was 5.1 days and the median was 4.0 days (range 1 to 19 days) 164 which has good efficacy against bacteria and viruses (including non-enveloped 170 viruses) (Omidbakhsh & Sattar, 2006) . After control measures were initiated, the outbreak slowed 171 and cases became sporadic, except for at Shelter 3 in January (due to communal housing).

In order to determine the pathogens that caused the outbreak, all 17 available fecal samples 196 were analyzed using viral metagenomics. Viral sequences assigned to five main viral families 197 (Anelloviridae, Parvoviridae, Papillomaviridae, Polyomaviridae and Caliciviridae) were 198 detected in these fecal samples (Table 3) . 199 (Table 4) . 269

Dependoparvovirus sequence reads were also found in two cats. A near full-length genome of 270 4315 bases could be assembled from cat #849 (also infected with fechavirus) whose 271 phylogenetic analysis showed it to be related to a recently reported dependoparvovirus genome 272 from bats (Desmodus rotundus) sharing NS1 and VP1 protein with 51.6% and 46.7% identities 273 (Supplementary Figure 1) . 274

The timeline of disease presentation and fecal shedding status of key animals in the 276 transmission chain between the 3 facilities was determined. There were no samples from cats in 277 Shelter 1 available for testing, but cat #688 was fechavirus positive shortly after being housed in 278 the same area as cat #853 and #614, who were sick upon transfer from Shelter 1 to Shelter 2. A 279 second cat in shelter 2 was also shedding fechavirus (cat #160). Of the other 15 affected cats in 280

Shelter 2 a total of 5 individual cats and a sample pool (mixed feces from 3 cats) were Using metagenomics, we found FeBoV1, 2, and 3 and a novel chaphamaparvovirus we named 311 fechavirus in a large fraction of fecal samples and fechavirus in all vomit samples from sick cats 312 in a multi-facility outbreak. Subsequent PCR testing confirmed the presence of either a bocavirus 313 or fechavirus or both (n=1 cat #283) of these viruses in all but one of the seventeen sick cats 314 tested (cat #178). The outbreak in shelter 2 predominantly tested positive for FeBoV (7/9 FeBoV 315 +ve and 2/9 fechavirus +ve) while the sick cats in shelter 3 were mainly shedding fechavirus (6/7 316 fechavirus +ve, 2/7 FeBov +ve). Another cat housed in shelter 2 who developed vomiting after 317 sick cats were transferred back from Shelter 3 was also shedding fechavirus as well as a novel 318 dependovirus. The co-detection of these viral genomes indicate that fechavirus may provide the 319 required help for replication-defective dependoviruses. 320 FPV and feline FCV reads were determined to originate from recently inoculated attenuated 321 vaccine strains while other viruses were deemed to be asymptomatic infections, derived from chicken and pork viruses in consumed food, or detected only in sporadic cases. FCV sequences 323 were negative by PCR, this could be the results of low viral load in those cats. 324

The close genetic relationship of fechavirus to cachavirus found in both diarrheic and healthy 325 dog feces (Fahsbender, Fechavirus  +  -+  -------+  +  -+  +  +  +  FeBoV  -+  -+  +  +  --+  +  -+  -----IDEXX diarrhea Note: Days (D1-D12) reflect day samples were collected. Days of illness are shaded starting at first sample collection. "+" and "-" means PCR positive or negative for the fechavirus. Illness onset was 10, 2, 2, 3 days before Day1 for cats #688, 912, 594 and 283, respectively. Figure 1 . Daily epidemic cases of the cat diarrhea outbreak in three shelters from November to January.

FIGREF0.text: have been found to infect cats, including rabies virus, feline rotavirus (FRV), feline 38 protoparvovirus virus (FPV), feline bocaviruses (FBoV), feline astroviruses (FeAstV), feline 39 picornaviruses (FePV), feline enteric coronavirus (FECV), feline calicivirus (FCV), feline 40 herpesvirus (FHV-1), feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV) and feline leukemia virus (FeLV) (Di 41 Martino, Di Profio, Melegari, & Marsilio, 2019; Ng et al., 2014; Pesavento & Murphy, 2014). 42 Diarrhea in cats is common and possible infectious causes include bacteria, parasites, and/or 43 viruses. Some of the most prevalent feline enteric viruses include FBoV, FeAstV, FRV, and FPV 44 (Ng et al., 2014; Otto et al., 2015; W. Zhang et al., 2014). Conditions in animal shelters 45 contribute to pathogen emergence due to factors including intensive housing, rapid population 46 turnover, animal stress, and the presence of many direct and indirect routes of possible exposure 47 (Pesavento & Murphy, 2014). 48 The Parvoviridae family consists of non-enveloped, icosahedral, viruses with single stranded 49 DNA genomes of 4 to 6Kb (Cotmore & Tattersall, 2014; Mietzsch, Penzes, & Agbandje-50 McKenna, 2019). Eight ICTV approved genera are currently included in the Parvoviridae family 51 (Cotmore et al., 2019). A recent reorganization of the Parvoviridae has proposed the creation of 52 a third subfamily named Hamaparvovirinae that includes invertebrate and vertebrate viruses as 53 well as endogenized genomes in the germ lines of fish and invertebrates suggesting an ancient 54 origin (Penzes, de Souza, Agbandje-McKenna, & Gifford, 2019; Souza et al., 2017). Vertebrate 55 infecting members of this subfamily are classified within the Chaphamaparvovirus genus 56 (previously labeled as unclassified or chapparvoviruses) have been identified in rats and mice 57 (Williams et al., 2018; Yang et al., 2016), bats (Baker et al., 2013; Yinda et al., 2018), rhesus 58 macaques (Kapusinszky, Ardeshir, Mulvaney, Deng, & Delwart, 2017), cynomologus macaques 59

FIGREF1.text: measures failed, the failure was traced to a contaminated environment or fomite. 173 PCR pathogen screening 174 Seventeen fecal samples from cats in Shelters 2 and 3 (collected after the outbreak was 175 recognized) were available for further analysis. Twelve samples representing 15 cats (i.e. 176 including two pools of multiple samples) were subjected to a comprehensive IDEXX feline 177 diarrhea panel pathogen screen (see materials and methods). FECV was detected in one sample, 178 Giardia DNA in 3 samples, and Clostridium perfringens alpha toxin DNA in 6 out of 11 cats that 179 tested, while Clostridium perfringens enterotoxin results were negative for all animals. 180 Clostridium perfringens is part of the normal feline intestinal flora; diarrheic and clinically 181 healthy cats shed the organism at similar rates (Marks, Rankin, Byrne, & Weese, 2011). Type A, 182 the most commonly isolated biotype, produces alpha-toxin and is commonly detected in feces of 183 both diarrheic and healthy dogs (Gizzi et al., 2014). It is not considered a primary cause of 184 diarrhea in cats, but may contribute to diarrhea in cases where a disturbance in the intestinal 185 microenvironment has occurred, such as due to concurrent pathogen infection (Adam, 2014). 186 Giardia is a protozoal parasite that can infect multiple mammalian species and can be associated 187 with diarrhea (and rarely, vomiting) in cats (Janeczko & Griffin, 2010). It has a prepatent period 188 of 5-16 days and while it can cause shelter outbreaks, it would not be capable of causing disease 189 only 24 hours after exposure (Janeczko & Griffin, 2010); a shelter outbreak of Giardia would 190 have a more indolent course. FRV was negative for all samples tested, only one sample (from a 191 pooled litter) was positive for FPV. These tests ruled out the primary bacterial differentials for a 192 shelter outbreak with a short incubation period. None of the positive organisms were considered 193 the main cause of the vomiting and diarrhea outbreak. 194

FIGREF2.text: Feline anellovirus were detected in 3 cats, and unclassified anelloviruses were detected in 201 another 4 cats. Anelloviruses are widely prevalent in humans and other mammals, and no clear 202 etiological role of anelloviruses has been identified (Y. Li et al., 2019; Moustafa et al., 2017). 203 Lyon-IARC polyomavirus and feline papillomavirus (Dyothetapappillomavirus 1) were shed by 204 one and two cats, respectively with both genomes showing nucleotide identity of ~ 99% with 205 those genomes previously reported in cats (Fahsbender, Altan, Estrada, et al., 2019; W. Zhang et 206 al., 2014). Lyon-IARC DNA was previously shown to be shed by 3/5 cat feces in a hoarding 207 situation diarrhea outbreak (one of which was co-infected with FPV) (Fahsbender, Altan, Estrada, 208 et al., 2019; W. Zhang et al., 2014). 209 Dietary contamination. 210 Chicken anemia virus (CAV), and gyrovirus 4 and 6 DNA from family Anelloviridae were 211 each detected in one cat. CAV is a highly prevalent chicken pathogen (Schat, 2009) and 212 gyroviruses have been frequently detected in human feces presumably originating from 213 consumed infected chicken. (Gia Phan et al., 2013; Niu et al., 2019). Also detected were two 214 sequence reads with a perfect match to porcine parvovirus 5 (Protoparvovirus genus) also likely 215 from consumed food (Xiao, Gimenez-Lirola, Jiang, Halbur, & Opriessnig, 2013). 216 Vaccine derived sequences. 217 All cats were vaccinated subcutaneously upon entry into the three facilities with Felocell 3 218 vaccine containing live attenuated FPV, FCV (mainly associated with respiratory systems in cats 219 (Radford, Coyne, Dawson, Porter, & Gaskell, 2007), and feline herpesvirus-1. That vaccine was 220 also sequenced using metagenomics yielding the near complete genome of the FCV (deposited in 221 GenBank MN868063), approximately 85.8% of the FPV genome, and more than 20,000 reads of 222 the herpes virus. Felocell 3 vaccine derived FPV and FCV sequences were compared to those 223 detected by metagenomics in two and four of the diarrheic cats respectively. The sequence reads 224 in the two cats shedding FPV showed 99%-100% identity to the vaccine sequences. The few 225 reads of FCV (1 to 4 sequences reads per sample) also showed a high level of similarity (99-226 100%) to the sequenced vaccine FCV genome. Given the extensive sequence diversity of FPV 227 and feline FCV (Abd-Eldaim, Potgieter, & Kennedy, 2005; Balboni et al., 2018; Battilani et al., metagenomics were vaccine derived. 230 Parvoviruses. 231 Viral sequences belonging to the Bocaparvovirus, and Chaphamaparvovirus genera were the 232 most abundant and detected in 14/17 cats(Table 3). Three different feline bocaparvoviruses 233 (FeBoV1-3) were shed by 3, 3 and 2 cats respectively. We then used a pan-FeBoV PCR to test 234 these 17 samples. One cat, FeBoV negative by metagenomics, was PCR positive (FeBoV2 by 235Sanger sequencing of PCR amplicon). Two other cats positive for bocaviruses with only 2 236 sequence reads were negative by PCR. All other PCR results were consistent with metagenomics 237 results (Table 3). All together FeBoV DNA was detected by metagenomics and/or PCR in 9also yielded sequence reads related to multiple parvoviruses in the 240Chaphamaparvovirus genus. Using de novo assembly and specific PCR to fill gaps, two near241 full-length genomes of 4225 and 4134 bases (Figure 3A) were generated from cats #594 and 242 #849 (GenBank accession numbers MN396757 and MN794869). The two genomes share 99.1% 243 identity of NS1 and 99.6% identity of VP1 at protein level, and 99.2% and 99.3% at nucleotide 244 level. These genomes encoded the two main ORFs shared by all parvoviruses, a 658aa ORF 245 encoding non-structural replication protein (NS1), and a 508aa ORF encoding viral capsid (VP1). 246 The closest relative to these genomes was a parvovirus recently reported in canine feces named 247 cachavirus (MK448316)(Fahsbender, Altan, Seguin, et al., 2019), with a nucleotide identity of 248 74.2% and NS1 and VP1 protein identity of 65.5% and 68.8% respectively. Other major ORFs 249 consisted of a 186aa ORF within the NS1 labeled NP and a potential 248aa ORF overlapping the 250 5'-UTR and NS1. The NP ORF is widely conserved in chaphamaparvoviruses (Christopher J. 251 Jolly, 2019; Roediger et al., 2018). No significant similarity was found for the 248aa ORF. 252 Under an April 2019 ICTV proposal updating the latest published classification (Cotmore et 253 al., 2019) members of the same parvovirus species should show >85% identity for NS1. The 254 fechavirus genome therefore qualifies as a member of a new species in the proposed 255 Chaphamaparvovirus genus. We named this novel virus feline chaphamaparvovirus or 256 fechavirus. Phylogenetic analysis confirmed the closest relative to be the canine cachavirus in 257 both NS and VP ORFs (Figure 3B and C). 258 Specific PCR primers were designed based on the fechavirus genomes and used to test all 17 259 fecal samples. Besides the six fechavirus positive fecal samples detected by NGS, two more 260 samples were positive by PCR. All four vomit samples tested (from unknown cats in shelter 3) 261 were also PCR positive. A total of 8 animals therefore shed fechavirus of which one was co-262 infected with FeBoV3 (Cat #283). Of the 17 animals available for analyzes only one was 263 negative for both FeBoV and fechavirus DNA (cat # 178). 264 Longitudinally collected fecal samples were collected from 4 cats and PCR tested for 265 fechavirus DNA. Cat #688 was fechavirus positive on the last day of his illness; while cats #912 266 and #283 were positive for a single time point while disease signs were manifest for a further 4 267 or 9 more days. Cat #594 shed fechavirus over 4 days while symptomatic plus a further 7 days 268 after recovery

FIGREF3.text: 3 positive. Fechavirus positive cat #160 was then in direct contact with subsequently 282 diseased cat #992 from shelter 3. Despite clean breaks imposed by cleaning and emptying the 283 facility in shelter 3 the disease continued to recur and spread. Of the seven cat fecal samples 284 available for study from shelter 3 fechavirus was detected in five and bocaparvovirus in 2 285 animals. Only a single case yielded both fechavirus and bocaparvovirus DNA (#283). A further 286 four vomit samples from unknown cat(s) in shelter 3 were all fechavirus PCR positive. Last, an 287 initially healthy cat in Shelter 2 developed disease signs immediately after cats from Shelter 3 288 were returned to Shelter 2 during the last wave of the outbreak and was found to be al., 2018; W. Zhang et al., 2014), and two protoparvovirus species, feline panleukopenia 295 virus (FPV)(Barrs, 2019) and feline bufavirus (FBuV) (Diakoudi et al., 2019). FeBoV1 was first 296 discovered in in multiple tissues of cats in Hong Kong (Lau et al., 2012) and subsequently 297 reported in cat feces in the US, Japan, Europe and China (Ng et al., 2014; Takano et al., 2016; Yi 298 et al., 2018; W. Zhang et al., 2014) . Similarly to human bocaparvovirus DNA commonly found 299 in the feces of healthy humans (Jartti et al., 2012; Kapoor et al., 2010; Ong, Schuurman, & 300 Heikens, 2016), frequent feline bocaparvovirus DNA detection in healthy cats raise questions 301 regarding its pathogenicity in cats (Diakoudi et al., 2019; Lau et al., 2012; Ng et al., 2014; 302 Piewbang, Kasantikul, Pringproa, & Techangamsuwan, 2019; W. Zhang et al., 2014). A recent 303 study showed a possible association between FBoV-1 infection, potentially aggravated by FPV, 304 and hemorrhagic enteritis (Diakoudi et al., 2019; Lau et al., 2012; Ng et al., 2014; Piewbang et 305 al., 2019; W. Zhang et al., 2014). FPV is an extensively studied pathogen that can lead to 306 reduction in circulating white blood cell and enteritis (Barrs, 2019; Truyen & Parrish, 2013). The 307 pathogenicity of FeBuV in cats is currently unknown (Diakoudi et al., 2019; Stuetzer & 308 Hartmann, 2014) but the virus shares very high sequence identity with a canine bufavirus 309 (Diakoudi et al., 2019; J. Li et al., 2019; Martella et al., 2018). 310

FIGREF4.text: Altan, Seguin, et al., 2019), may reflects a cross-carnivore virus 326 transmission as occurred with FPV mutating into the highly pathogenic canine parvovirus 327 (Allison et al., 2013; Hoelzer, Shackelton, Parrish, & Holmes, 2008). 328 Daily collected fecal samples from symptomatic cats revealed transient shedding for 3/4 329 animals with fechavirus DNA only detected at a single time point. One animal shed fechavirus 330 DNA during all twelve days of sampling both while exhibiting disease signs and seven days after 331 disease resolution. The short duration of fechavirus shedding for 3/4 animals, also typical of FPV 332 shedding (Bergmann et al., 2019), may account for its non-detection in some of the affected 333 animals in shelter 2 and 3. All but one of the fechavirus negative samples were positive for one 334 of three different feline bocavirus indicating that both bocaviruses and fechavirus were 335 circulating in these shelters. Because of the high diversity of bocaviruses found here, belonging 336 to three distinct species, and the typically asymptomatic nature of FeBoV infections, a role for 337 bocaviruses in the multi-facility transmission of this disease outbreak seems unlikely. A 338 pathogenic role for fechavirus seems more likely as viral DNA was detected in key animals with 339 contacts across the three facilities experiencing outbreaks with similar disease signs. 340 A key clinical attribute of this unusual outbreak was the prominence of indirect routes of 341 transmission, including ongoing fomite transmission after robust control measures were 342 implemented. Another notable characteristic of this case was the very short minimum incubation 343 period. Combined with the absence of any known pathogen identified on routine screening, this 344 points to a novel non-enveloped enteric virus as the most likely causative agent. Animal shelters 345 and veterinary hospitals should maintain good routine infection control procedures and consider 346 novel viruses, including fechavirus, in the diagnosis of feline gastrointestinal disease. 347

TABREF0.text: Epidemic and clinical data 137 A vomiting and diarrhea outbreak was identified across three animal shelters in British 138 Columbia, Canada lasting from Nov. 2018 to Jan. 2019. A total of 43 cats met the case definition 139 (see methods). 17 samples from 19 cats (including a pool of samples from 3 cats), plus four 140 vomit samples, were available for further studies. 141 The outbreak was first identified on November 24, 2018 in Shelter 2 when 8/12 cats housed 142 in the main adoption room became sick with vomiting and diarrhea. Diet, environmental, and 143 toxic causes of the outbreak were ruled out clinically and an outbreak investigation initiated. The 144 first cases in Shelter 2 (#614, #853) had arrived from Shelter 1 via the organization's animal 145 transfer program on November 15, 2018 and were sick during or shortly after transport. Upon 146 further investigation, the originating shelter, Shelter 1, had 11 more sick cats. On November 20, 147

TABREF1.text: . No recovered cats relapsed and there were no cases where 165 transmission was traced to a clinically recovered animal.The sheltering organization initiated control measures on November 24, 2018 including 167 cessation of all cat movement, personal protective equipment (gowns, gloves, caps, shoe covers) 168 in all cat housing areas, and enhanced sanitation measures using accelerated hydrogen peroxide, 169

TABREF2.text: In this study, we characterized the virome from a cat diarrhea and vomiting outbreak, and 348 showed that besides different FeBoV, a new chaphamaparvovirus was associated with 349 gastrointestinal disease. Future studies on its prevalence, genetic diversity, and tissue distribution350 in healthy and diarrheic cats are needed to further investigate a possible etiologic role in feline 351 diseases. 352 Author Contributions: Conceptualization, YL, EG, ED; Data curation, YL, EG, AI, EA, MAS, 354 ME, XD; Formal analysis, YL, EG, ED; Methodology, YL, EG; Supervision, ED, EG; Writing 355 original draft, YL, EG, ED; Writing review and editing, YL, EG, ED. 356 Acknowledgments: The authors would like to acknowledge Melissa Beall, Roxanne Chan, and 357 Phyllis Tyrrel from IDEXX for helpful comments and assistance with clinical data. Funding 358 from IDEXX and the Vitalant Research Institute. 359 Conflicts of Interest: The other authors declare no conflicts of interest. 360 Ethics Statement: The authors confirm that the ethical policies of the journal, as noted on the 361 journal's author guidelines, have been adhered to. No ethical approval was required as samples 362 were collected as part of routine outbreak investigation. 363 Data Availability Statement: The data that supports the findings of this study are available in 364 the main body of this article. 365 Attack rates (AR) for selected rooms and dates where widespread or complete exposure was suspected.
